00279 
00280 //  CTCLVariable.cpp
00281 // Encapsulates a TCL Variable.  TCL Variables are string valued.
00282 // Their contents can be gotten or set.  in addition, by deriving
00283 // from this class, overriding operator(), and invoking Trace()
00284 // Action can be taken each time a variable is to be set.
00285 // Finally, the value of a variable can be bound to other
00286 // storage
00287 //
00288 //   Author:
00289 //      Ron Fox
00290 //      NSCL
00291 //      Michigan State University
00292 //      East Lansing, MI 48824-1321
00293 //      mailto:fox@nscl.msu.edu
00294 //
00296 
00297 //
00298 // Header Files:
00299 //
00300 
00301 #include "TCLVariable.h"                               
00302 #include "TCLInterpreter.h"
00303 #include <tcl.h>
00304 #include <histotypes.h>
00305 #include <assert.h>
00306 
00307 static const char* Copyright= Copyright = 
00308 "CTCLVariable.cpp: Copyright 1999 NSCL, All rights reserved\n";
00309 
00310 // Functions for class CTCLVariable
00311 
00312 CTCLVariable::~CTCLVariable ( ) {
00313   m_sVariable = "";
00314   if(m_fTracing) UnTrace();
00315 }
00316 
00317 
00319 //
00320 //  Function:   
00321 //    char*  operator() ( char* pName, char* pSubscript, int Flags )
00322 //  Operation Type:
00323 //     Trace handler.
00324 //
00325 char*  
00326 CTCLVariable::operator()(char* pName, char* pSubscript, int Flags) 
00327 {
00328 // Called when trace is enabled on a variable.
00329 // This function is called either just before returning
00330 //  the variable's value on read
00331 //  or just after setting the value on write.
00332 //  
00333 // Formal Parameters:
00334 //    char* pName:
00335 //        Name of the variable being modified.
00336 //   char* pSubscript:
00337 //       Subscript of the variable, if the var is an array, or NULL
00338 //       if not.
00339 //   Int_t Flags:
00340 //      One or more of the following bits:
00341 //         TCL_TRACE_READS      - If Read invoked the trace.
00342 //         TCL_TRACE_WRITES     - If Write invoked the trace.
00343 //         TCL_TRACE_UNSET      - If an unset invoked the trace.
00344 //         TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY      - If the variable is global and not
00345 //                                reachable from the current script
00346 //                                execution context.
00347 //         TCL_TRACE_DESTROYED  - variable is being UNSET only.
00348 //         TCL_INTERP_DESTROYED - Interpreter which owns the variable
00349 //                                is being destroyed don't call it.
00350 // NOTE:
00351 //   Default implementation of this function is a no-op.
00352 //
00353 // Returns:
00354 //    NULL If all is ok else a pointer to a static character string describing
00355 //   an error.
00356 //
00357 
00358   return "Unimplemented variable trace.";
00359 
00360 }
00362 //
00363 //  Function:   
00364 //    char* TraceRelay ( ClientData pObject, Tcl_Interp* pInterpreter, 
00365 //                       char* pName, char* pIndex, int flags )
00366 //  Operation Type:
00367 //     contextualizer
00368 //
00369 char* 
00370 CTCLVariable::TraceRelay(ClientData pObject, Tcl_Interp* pInterpreter, 
00371                          char* pName, 
00372                          char* pIndex, 
00373                          int flags) 
00374 {
00375 // This is the actual trace function set by the Trace() method.
00376 //  We use the ClientData to establish object context and
00377 //  invoke the operator() virtual member.  
00378 // 
00379 // Formal Parameters:
00380 //      ClientData   pObject:
00381 //          Actually a pointer to the object whose operator() is
00382 //          invoked.
00383 //      Tcl_Interp* pInterp:
00384 //          Interpreter in which context the variable is being affected.
00385 //          note that this function will. It is an assertion failuerable
00386 //          offense for this interpreter not to match the interpreter
00387 //          the variable is bound to.
00388 //
00389 //      char* pName:
00390 //           Name of the variable being traced.
00391 //      char* pSubscript:
00392 //           If the variable is an array, the index being traced.
00393 //       int flags:
00394 //           Tcl flags, see operator() for values.
00395 // 
00396 
00397   CTCLVariable*     pVariable = (CTCLVariable*)pObject;
00398   CTCLInterpreter*  pInterp   = pVariable->AssertIfNotBound();
00399 
00400   if((flags & TCL_INTERP_DESTROYED) == 0)
00401     assert(pInterp->getInterpreter() == pInterpreter);
00402 
00403   return pVariable->operator()(pName, pIndex, flags);
00404 
00405 }
00407 //
00408 //  Function:   
00409 //    char* Set ( char* pValue, int flags=TCL_LEAVE_ERR_MSG )
00410 //  Operation Type:
00411 //     modifier
00412 //
00413 const char* 
00414 CTCLVariable::Set(const char* pValue, int flags) 
00415 {
00416 // Sets the variable with a new value.
00417 // 
00418 // Formal Parameters:
00419 //       char* pNewValue:
00420 //           New value for the variable.
00421 //       int flags = TCL_LEAVE_ERR_MSG:
00422 //           set flags which can be any of:
00423 //              TCL_GLOBAL_ONLY      - Reference global regardless of context.
00424 //              TCL_LEAVE_ERR_MSG - leave error message in result if fails.
00425 //              TCL_APPEND_VALUE    - Append value to existing string.
00426 //              TCL_LIST_ELEMENT      - Treat value as list element. 
00427 //  Returns:
00428 //      NULL - success
00429 //      pointer to static error message otherwise.
00430 
00431   CTCLInterpreter* pInterp = AssertIfNotBound();
00432 
00433   return Tcl_SetVar(pInterp->getInterpreter(), 
00434                     (char*)(m_sVariable.c_str()), (char*)pValue, flags);
00435 
00436 
00437 }
00439 //
00440 //  Function:   
00441 //    char* Set ( char* pSubscript, char* pValue, int flags=TCL_LEAVE_ERR_MSG )
00442 //  Operation Type:
00443 //     Modifier
00444 //
00445 const char* 
00446 CTCLVariable::Set(const char* pSubscript, char* pValue, int flags) 
00447 {
00448 // See Set(char* pName, int flags) for most of the details, this function
00449 // accepts an additional string parameter (first one) which is either the index
00450 // to the variable as an array or a NULL if the variable is to be treated as 
00451 //  a scalar.
00452 
00453   CTCLInterpreter* pInterp = AssertIfNotBound();
00454   
00455   return Tcl_SetVar2(pInterp->getInterpreter(),
00456                      (char*)(m_sVariable.c_str()), (char*)pSubscript, 
00457                      (char*)pValue, flags);
00458 
00459 }
00461 //
00462 //  Function:   
00463 //    char* Get ( int flags=TCL_LEAVE_ERR_MSG, char* pIndex=0 )
00464 //  Operation Type:
00465 //     Interogatory
00466 //
00467 const char* 
00468 CTCLVariable::Get(int flags, char* pIndex) 
00469 {
00470 // Returns the value of a variable.   NULL is returned on
00471 // error.
00472 //
00473 // Formal Parameters:
00474 //     int flags:
00475 //        flag values:
00476 //        See Set().
00477 //     char* pIndex=0
00478 //          If variable is an array, this specifies the index.
00479 //
00480   CTCLInterpreter* pInterp = AssertIfNotBound();
00481 
00482   const char* p = Tcl_GetVar2(pInterp->getInterpreter(),
00483                               (char*)(m_sVariable.c_str()), pIndex, flags);
00484   return p;
00485 
00486 }
00488 //
00489 //  Function:   
00490 //    void Link ( void* pVariable, int Type )
00491 //  Operation Type:
00492 //     connector
00493 //
00494 int
00495 CTCLVariable::Link(void* pVariable, int Type) 
00496 {
00497 // Connects a program variable to a 
00498 // TCL variable.  Note that this variable can be
00499 // a member of an object as long as it will be unlinked
00500 // prior to destruction.    
00501 // 
00502 // Formal Parameters:
00503 //     char* pName:
00504 //       Name of the variable
00505 //     void* pAddress:
00506 //        Pointer to the linked variable.
00507 //     int type:
00508 //        any of:
00509 //      TCL_LINK_INT         - pAddress -> int
00510 //      TCL_LINK_DOUBLE- pAddress -> double
00511 //      TCL_LINK_STRING - pAddress -> char*
00512 //          possibly or'd with:
00513 //      TCL_LINK_READ_ONLY - Variable should be treated as TCL readonly.
00514 //
00515 // Returns:
00516 //     TCL_OK - if link performed (?)
00517 
00518   CTCLInterpreter* pInterp = AssertIfNotBound();
00519 
00520   return Tcl_LinkVar(pInterp->getInterpreter(), (char*)(m_sVariable.c_str()),
00521                      (char*)pVariable, Type);
00522 
00523 }
00525 //
00526 //  Function:   
00527 //    void Unlink (  )
00528 //  Operation Type:
00529 //     connector
00530 //
00531 void 
00532 CTCLVariable::Unlink() 
00533 {
00534 // Removes a link between a variable and a TCL Variable.
00535 
00536   CTCLInterpreter* pInterp = AssertIfNotBound();
00537 
00538   Tcl_UnlinkVar(pInterp->getInterpreter(), (char*)(m_sVariable.c_str()));
00539 
00540 }
00542 //
00543 //  Function:   
00544 //    int Trace (  )
00545 //  Operation Type:
00546 //     connector
00547 //
00548 int 
00549 CTCLVariable::Trace(int flags, char* pIndex) 
00550 {
00551 // Sets a trace on the variable.  When the variable is
00552 // accessed,  TraceRelay  is called which sets up a call
00553 // to operator().
00554 // NOTE:
00555 //     Typically this should only be called on an object of a class
00556 //     derived from CTCLVariable since that's the only way to 
00557 //     get an operator() which does anything.
00558   //
00559   // Formal Parameters:
00560   //     int flags:
00561   //        Bitwise or of any of the following:
00562   //        TCL_TRACE_READS    - Reads of the variable are traced.
00563   //        TCL_TRACE_WRITES   - Writes of the variable are traced.
00564   //        TCL_TRACE_UNSETS   - Unsets of the variable are traced.
00565   //        Default is to set all of these flags.
00566   //     char* pIndex:
00567   //        If the variable is an array, specifies which element should
00568   //        be traced.  Note that for scalars, this should be  NULL.
00569   //        Defaults to kpNULL
00570   //
00571   CTCLInterpreter* pInterp = AssertIfNotBound();
00572 
00573   if(m_fTracing)UnTrace();      // Remove any trace already set.
00574   int status = Tcl_TraceVar2(pInterp->getInterpreter(), 
00575                              (char*)(m_sVariable.c_str()), pIndex,
00576                              flags, TraceRelay, (ClientData)this);
00577   if(status == TCL_OK) {
00578     m_fTracing = kfTRUE;
00579     m_nTraceFlags = flags;
00580     m_sTraceIndex = pIndex ? pIndex : "";
00581   }
00582   return status;
00583 }
00585 //
00586 //  Function:   
00587 //    void UnTrace ()
00588 //  Operation Type:
00589 //     
00590 //
00591 void 
00592 CTCLVariable::UnTrace() 
00593 {
00594 // Remove trace on variable.
00595 //  Formal Parameters:
00596 //    Index of the array element from which to remove trace.
00597 
00598  
00599   if(m_fTracing) {
00600     CTCLInterpreter *pInterp = AssertIfNotBound();
00601 
00602     Tcl_UntraceVar2(pInterp->getInterpreter(),
00603                     (char*)(m_sVariable.c_str()), 
00604                     (char*)(m_sTraceIndex.size() ? m_sTraceIndex.c_str() : 
00605                                            (char*)kpNULL),
00606                     m_nTraceFlags, TraceRelay, (ClientData)this);
00607   }
00608 
00609 }
00611 //
00612 // Function:
00613 //    void DoAssign(const CTCLVariable& rRhs)
00614 // Operation Type:
00615 //    Protected utility.
00616 //
00617 void
00618 CTCLVariable::DoAssign(const CTCLVariable& rRhs)
00619 {
00620   // Does the grunt work of the various assignment like
00621 
00622   if(m_fTracing) UnTrace();
00623 
00624   m_sVariable    = rRhs.m_sVariable;
00625   m_fTracing     = rRhs.m_fTracing;
00626   m_nTraceFlags  = rRhs.m_nTraceFlags;
00627   m_sTraceIndex  = rRhs.m_sTraceIndex;
00628 
00629   if(m_fTracing) {
00630     Trace(m_nTraceFlags, (char*)(m_sTraceIndex.size() ? 
00631                                       m_sTraceIndex.c_str() : 
00632                                       (const char*)kpNULL));
00633   }
00634 
00635 }
00636 
00637 
00644 void
00645 CTCLVariable::Update()
00646 {
00647   Tcl_Interp* pInterp = getInterpreter()->getInterpreter();
00648   Tcl_UpdateLinkedVar(pInterp, (char*)m_sVariable.c_str());
00649 }
